questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with a voice that sounds similar to that of a female, characterized by a high-pitched voice despite the completion of puberty. What could be a potential underlying cause related to the vocal cords for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Immature growth of vocal cords leading to lengthening of vocal cords

options.label: B
options.text: Immature growth of vocal cords leading to relative shortening of vocal cords

options.label: C
options.text: Immature growth of vocal cords leading to incomplete closure of the anterior part of vocal cords

options.label: D
options.text: Immature growth of vocal cords leading to excessive thickening of vocal cords

questions.correct_answer: B. Immature growth of vocal cords leading to relative shortening of vocal cords

questions.text: A 35-year-old teacher complains of hoarseness, vocal fatigue, and a weak voice, especially after prolonged speaking. Laryngoscopic examination reveals keyhole appearance of the glottis during phonation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Phonasthenia

Puberphonia

(Option A)

Functional Aphonia

(Option C)

Hysteric Aphonia

(Option D)

Definition

Vocal fatigue due to weakness in the thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid muscles causing vocal cord bowing

Mutational falsetto with persistent high-pitched voice after puberty, more common in males

Psychogenic voice disorder with loss of voluntary voice despite normal vocal cord structure

Conversion disorder with sudden voice loss due to psychological stress

Features
  • Weak, fatigued voice after speaking
  • Keyhole appearance of the glottis from vocal cord bowing
  • High-pitched voice not congruent with age or gender
  • Thin, weak voice quality
  • No structural abnormalities in the larynx or vocal cords
  • Inability to produce voice voluntarily
  • Able to cough or whisper, indicating normal vocal cord function
  • Sudden inability to speak after emotional distress
  • No organic pathology affecting the larynx

Laryngoscopic Findings

Keyhole appearance of the glottis from vocal cord bowing

False vocal cord hypertrophy

Vocal cords do not fully adduct during phonation but work normally during reflexive actions like coughing

Vocal cords appear normal but may not come together during speech attempts. Patients can cough or whisper

Management
  • Voice therapy to strengthen vocal muscles
  • Thyroplasty for severe cases
  • Voice Therapy: pitch adjustment through vocal techniques with a speech therapist.
  • Type III Thyroplasty: Surgery to lower pitch by altering vocal cord tension.

Counseling and voice therapy

Psychological support and speech therapy

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery to remove a benign mass from the larynx. For direct laryngoscopy, which of the following positions is most preferred to provide optimal visualization and access to the larynx?
questions.explanation:
Category

Indications

Diagnostic
  • Infeasibility of Indirect Laryngoscopy (e.g. in infants/young children with symptoms suggesting laryngeal/hypopharyngeal pathology)
  • Failure of Indirect Laryngoscopy (e.g. excessive gag reflex, overhanging epiglottis)
  • Examination of Hidden Areas (e.g. hypopharynx: base of tongue, valleculae, lower piriform fossa; larynx: infrahyoid epiglottis, anterior commissure, ventricles, subglottic region)
  • Determining Extent and Biopsy (e.g. to assess growths and obtain biopsy samples)

Therapeutic
  • Removal of Benign Lesions (e.g., papillomas, fibromas, vocal nodules, polyps, cysts)
  • Foreign Body Extraction (from the larynx and hypopharynx)
  • Dilatation of Laryngeal Strictures

Aspect

Barking Dog Position

Rose Position

Position

Supine (lying on the back), head in slight extension, chin elevated, neutral or slightly extended neck

Supine (lying on the back) with neck hyperextended, head in more pronounced extension, chin raised

Primary Use

Used for laryngoscopy; provides a clear view of the glottis and vocal cords, ideal for intubation.

Used for thyroid surgeries and other neck procedures; offers better exposure of the thyroid gland and surrounding structures.

questions.text: During an indirect laryngoscopy, which of the following laryngeal structures is typically not visible?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Indirect Laryngoscopy

Direct Laryngoscopy

Technique

Uses a small laryngeal mirror and light source


 

Uses a laryngoscope with light and camera or lens




 

Visualization

Reflective image of the larynx

Direct and detailed view of the larynx

Structures Visible

Epiglottis, aryepiglottic fold, false cords, true cords, pyriform fossa, postcricoid region, posterior pharyngeal wall, median and lateral glossoepiglottic folds

Complete view of the larynx, including vocal cords, epiglottis, arytenoids, and other detailed structures

Structures Not Visible

May not fully visualize anterior commissure

No significant structures are missed in the larynx

Indications

Routine examination of voice disorders and throat symptoms (primarily diagnostic)

Diagnostic and therapeutic procedures, intubation

Advantages

Less invasive, quick, no specialized equipment needed

Clear, detailed view, allows for interventions

Limitations

Less detailed view, challenging in some anatomical variations

More invasive, requires sedation or anesthesia

Setting

Office or outpatient setting

Operating room or clinical setting

Patient Comfort

Generally well-tolerated

May cause discomfort, require anesthesia or sedation

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with a change of voice for 3 months and, on examination, is found to have unilateral superior laryngeal nerve paralysis that has no scope for improvement. Which of the following thyroplasty is recommended in this case?
questions.explanation:
Type I/Medialization thyroplasty

Type II

(Option A)

Type III

(Option C)

Type IV

(Option B)
  • It is the medial displacement of the vocal cord using an implant placed in the thyroid cartilage via a window.
  • Indications:
    • Unilateral vocal cord paralysis
    • Bilateral bowed vocal cords due to aging
    • Soft tissue defects of vocal cords
    • Adductor palsy
    • Unilateral complete (recurrent & superior laryngeal nerve) palsy
       
  • A waiting period of 12 months is necessary and injection laryngoplasty must be done during this time.
  • It is lateral displacement of the vocal cord.
  • Involves the insertion of a shim to separate the anterior vocal cords.
  • Indication:
    • Abductor palsy
    • Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy


 
  • Used to shorten (relax) the vocal cord
  • This lowers the pitch
  • Indications:
    • Mutational falsetto/ Puberphonia
    • Gender transformation surgery from female to male
  • Used to lengthen (tighten) the vocal cord
  • It elevates the pitch
  • Indications:
    • Androphonia
    • Gender transformation from male to female
    • Lax vocal cord and bowing due to age or trauma

Thyroplasty (or Isshiki’s thyroplasty)

Type 1

Proximal/medialization of vocal cord

For adductor palsy, U/L complete VC palsy

Type 2

Lateralization of vocal cord

For abductor palsy, B/L RLN palsy

Type 3

Shortening/relaxation of vocal cord

For puberphonia

Type 4

Tightening/lengthening of vocal cord

For androphonia

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with an inspirational stridor immediately after birth, which increases on crying. The stridor is alleviated when the baby is placed in the prone position, and the cry is normal. The flexible laryngoscopy is shown as follows.
questions.explanation:
Laryngomalacia or Congenital Laryngeal Stridor

  • Most common congenital abnormality of the larynx.
  • During inspiration, an excessively flaccid supraglottic larynx gets sucked in and causes the symptoms.

Clinical Features
  • Presents at birth or immediately after
  • Stridor:
    • Increases on crying (increased negative intrathoracic pressure pulls the epiglottis inward, covering the laryngeal inlet)
    • Stridor present in supine position (as the epiglottis covers the laryngeal inlet)
    • Subsides in prone position (as the epiglottis falls away from the larynx)
  • Cyanosis seen sometimes
  • Normal cry
  • Usually disappears by 2 years of age

Investigations
  • Direct laryngoscopy:
    • Elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself giving an “omega-shaped” appearance.
    • Floppy aryepiglottic folds
    • Prominent aretynoids
  • Flexible laryngoscopy is the most preferred

Management
  • Conservative treatment in most cases
  • Tracheostomy: If severe respiratory obstruction
  • Supraglottoplasty: If severe laryngomalacia

questions.text: Which of the following statements about subglottic stenosis is true?

options.label: B
options.text: Grade I subglottis stenosis usually requires surgical intervention

options.label: C
options.text: A subglottic diameter of less than 4mm in a full-term neonate makes the diagnosis

options.label: D
options.text: The degree of strictures is measured by MRI

questions.correct_answer: C. A subglottic diameter of less than 4mm in a full-term neonate makes the diagnosis
questions.explanation:
The Myer-Cotton grading of laryngotracheal stenosis

 

Management
 

Grade I: 0-50% obstruction

Grade I subglottic stenosis usually requires no surgical intervention. (Option B)

Grade II: 51-70% obstruction (Option A)

Grade II stenosis can be reconstructed by means of a laryngotracheal reconstruction (LTR).
 

Grade III: 71-99% obstruction
 
  • Mild grade III stenosis repaired by anterior graft with posterior cricoid split +/- posterior cartilage grafting.
  • Severe grade III stenosis repaired by anterior and posterior grafts.
 

Grade IV: 100% obstruction
  • Grade IV stenosis needs anterior and posterior grafts with prolonged stenting.
 
  • Partial cricotracheal resection (PCTR) can be done for severe grade III and grade IV stenosis.

questions.text: A baby presents with biphasic stridor and severe respiratory obstruction necessitating intubation. Identify the false statement about this condition.

options.label: A
options.text: Presents with a weak, high-pitched, squeaky voice

options.label: B
options.text: A CO2 laser is used in the endoscopic management of this condition

options.label: D
options.text: The cry is normal in this condition

questions.correct_answer: D. The cry is normal in this condition
questions.explanation:
Laryngeal webs
  • Laryngeal webs are formed due to the failure of complete canalization of the larynx during embryogenesis.
  • It leads to the formation of glottic (Option C) or, very rarely, a supraglottic web and causes variable degrees of respiratory obstruction and dysphonia as per the length of the vocal cord involved.
 

Clinical features
  • Severe respiratory obstruction
  • Dysphonia
  • Biphasic stridor
  • Weak, high-pitched, squeaky voice (Option A)
  • Weak cry or aphonia from birth





 

Management (depends on thickness of web)
  • Thin web: endoscopic division along the margin of one vocal cord with a knife or CO2 laser (Option B)
     
  • Thick web: excision via laryngofissure and a silicon keel is placed endoscopically to prevent recurrence for 2 weeks

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby is having an inspiratory stridor that has worsened from the day of onset. An endoscopy is done and shows a compressible, pear-shaped red swelling in the subglottis on the left side. The baby also has a reddish lesion over her trunk. What is the first line of treatment for this condition?
A 3-year-old child has stridor only during inspiration. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Stridor

1. Inspiratory Stridor

2. Expiratory Stridor

3. Biphasic Stridor

Site of Lesion

Produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx (extrathoracic obstruction).

Produced in lesions of the thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi (intrathoracic obstruction).

Produced in lesions of glottis, subglottis and cervical trachea.

Mechanism

In extrathoracic obstruction:

During inspiration → intratracheal pressure falls below atmospheric pressure → airway collapse

In intrathoracic obstruction:

During expiration → elevated pleural pressure compresses the airway → reduction in airway size at the site of obstruction

In glottic or subglottic obstruction:

Airway segment → remains unchanged during respiration

Example

  • Laryngomalacia
  • Retropharyngeal abscess (Option C)
  • Bronchial foreign body (Option A)
  • Tracheal stenosis
  • Laryngeal papillomas (Option B)
  • Vocal cord paralysis
  • Subglottic stenosis (Option D)

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate presents with stridor. Which condition is not typically associated with stridor in this age group?
questions.explanation:
Causes

Naso- and Oropharyngeal

Laryngeal

Tracheal

Congenital

  • Choanal atresia (Option B)
  • Choanal stenosis
  • Mid-nasal stenosis
  • Pyriform aperture stenosis
  • Glioma
  • Encephalocele
  • Meningocele
  • Dermoid/teratoma
  • Craniofacial abnormalities
  • Micrognathia- glossoptosis
  • Lingual thyroid
  • Lymphovascular malformation
  • Laryngomalacia
  • Vocal cord palsy (Option D)
  • Laryngeal stenosis
  • Laryngeal cysts
  • Webs
  • Laryngeal atresia
  • Vallecular cyst
  • Arytenoid fixation
  • Posterior laryngeal cleft
  • Tracheal stenosis
  • Tracheal atresia
  • Trapped first tracheal ring
  • Complete rings
  • Micro (stovepipe) trachea
  • Haemangioma
  • Primary and secondary tracheomalacia- vascular compression

Acquired - Neonates

Neonatal rhinitis
  • Intubation trauma (Option C)
  • Surgical trauma (e.g. laser)
  • Laryngeal stenosis
  • Arytenoid fixation
  • Reflux laryngitis
  • Post-intubation/ instrumentation/ tracheal stenosis
  • Reflux tracheitis

Acquired - Children
  • Allergic rhinitis
  • Adenoiditis
  • Adenotonsillar hypertrophy
  • Foreign body
  • Non-allergic rhinitis
  • Retropharyngeal abscess
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Ludwig's angina
  • Thermal and caustic burns
  • Intubation trauma
  • Croup
  • Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis
  • Hereditary angioedema
  • Epidermolysis bullosa
  • Foreign body
  • Dislocated arytenoid
  • Epiglottitis (Option A)
  • Trauma -fracture
  • Caustic and thermal burns
  • Haemangioma
  • Lymphovascular malformation
  • Croup
  • Bacterial tracheitis
  • Foreign body
  • Localized malacia secondary to a tracheostomy or TOF repair
  • Thyroid masses
  • Lymphovascular malformation
  • Mediastinal tumors

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with severe maxillofacial trauma. He cannot be intubated and is showing signs of hypoxia. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Cricothyrotomy

Definition

Procedure for opening the airway through the cricothyroid membrane.

Indication

  • Emergency cricothyrotomy is indicated in any CICO (Cannot Intubate, Cannot Oxygenate) scenario.
  • Situations that may lead to CICO include:
    • Oral or maxillofacial trauma
    • Cervical spine trauma
    • Profuse oral hemorrhage
    • Copious emesis
    • Anatomic abnormalities preventing endotracheal intubation

Clinical Significance

Cricothyrotomy is the final step in the difficult airway algorithm for CICO scenarios.

Types

1. Needle or Small Bore Cannula Cricothyrotomy:

  • A narrow-caliber rigid needle or flexible cannula is inserted through the cricothyroid membrane.
  • Limited for temporary use due to inadequate gas exchange, risking hypercarbia.

2. Large Cannula Cricothyrotomy:

  • Cannula (>4mm internal diameter) provides adequate ventilation with standard breathing systems.
  • Exhalation occurs through the cannula, even with complete upper airway obstruction.

3. Surgical Cricothyrotomy:

  • Involves making a 3 cm midline incision, followed by a horizontal incision in the inferior part of the cricothyroid membrane, and the insertion of a 6mm tube.
  • Cricothyrotomy tubes should be converted to tracheostomies within a few days to prevent dysphonia and subglottic stenosis.

Complications

  • Bleeding
  • Lacerations of tracheal cartilage
  • Perforation of the trachea
  • Creation of a false tract
  • Infection
  • Long-term complications: Subglottic stenosis, Voice change

Contraindications

  • No absolute contraindications in CICO scenarios.
  • Relative contraindications:
    • Known tracheal surgery
    • Fractured larynx
    • Laryngotracheal disruption
    • Children

Image

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with severe asthma and airway edema is admitted to the ICU after multiple failed intubation attempts. Which type of procedure is most suitable for ensuring long-term airway management?
questions.explanation:
High Tracheostomy (Option A)

Mid-Tracheostomy

(Option C)

Low Tracheostomy

(Option B)
  • Location: Done above the thyroid isthmus (isthmus lies against 1st, 2nd, and 4th tracheal rings) and involves the 1st tracheal ring.
  • Risks: Perichondritis of cricoid cartilage and subglottic stenosis.
  • Only Indication: Carcinoma of the larynx (since the entire larynx will be removed, and a new tracheostome will be made lower).
  • Location: Done through the 2nd or 3rd tracheal rings and involves the division of or retraction of the thyroid isthmus to expose the trachea.
  •  
  • Most Preferred technique
  • The procedure
  • Location: Done below the level of thyroid isthmus (below the 3rd tracheal ring).
  • Challenges:
    • Trachea is deeper at this level.
    • Close proximity to large blood vessels.
    • Difficulty with tracheostomy tube impinging on the suprasternal notch.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman in need of long-term airway maintenance was treated by tracheostomy. The tracheostomy tube has developed a partial obstruction in the following days. Which of the following steps is not necessary to manage this situation?

A 5-year-old child presents with complete airway obstruction after swallowing a coin and is showing signs of hypoxia. The Heimlich maneuver has failed. X-rays of the neck are shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Initiate advanced airway management with intubation

questions.explanation:
Tracheal Foreign Body

Laryngeal Foreign Body
  • Sharp Foreign Body: Cough and hemoptysis.
  • Loose Foreign Body (e.g., seed): May move between carina and vocal cords, causing:
    • "Audible slap" and "palpatory thud"
    • Asthmatoid wheeze heard best at patient’s open mouth
  • Complete Obstruction: Can cause asphyxia and sudden death unless urgent resuscitative measures are taken urgently.
  • Partial Obstruction: Cause discomfort or pain in throat, hoarseness, stridor, cough, aphonia, dyspnea, wheezing, and hemoptysis.

Radiology: Soft Tissue X-ray: PA and lateral views of neck in its extended position for radio-opaque and sometimes radiolucent foreign body in larynx/trachea.
  • Emergency removal of foreign bodies is not typically indicated unless:
    • Airway obstruction is present.
    • Foreign bodies are of vegetable origin (e.g., seeds) and likely to swell.
  • Methods for Foreign Body Removal
  1. Rigid bronchoscopy.
  2. Bronchoscopy with C-arm fluoroscopy.
  3. Use of Dormia basket or Fogarty's balloon for rounded objects. (Option A)
  4. Tracheostomy first followed by bronchoscopy through the tracheostome.
  5. Thoracotomy and bronchotomy for peripheral foreign bodies.
  6. Flexible fiberoptic bronchoscopy in selected adult patients.

Complete Obstruction:

  • A large bolus of food above the vocal cords may cause total aphonia (inability to cry for help).
  • Immediate First Aid Measures:
    • Back pounding.
    • Turn the patient upside down.
    • Back Blows (for infants <1 year): Place the infant face down over the rescuer’s arm, head lower than the trunk, and deliver five back blows between the scapulae.
  • Heimlich Maneuver (for >1 year):
    • Should not be done if only partial obstruction, for fear of causing total obstruction
    • Procedure: Stand behind the patient and wrap arms around the lower chest.
    • Perform four abdominal thrusts to use residual air in the lungs to dislodge the foreign body.
  • If Heimlich fails: Perform cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy to secure the airway. (Option B)
  • Post-Emergency: Foreign body removal using direct laryngoscopy or laryngofissure if the object is impacted. (Option C)

questions.text: A 3-year-old presents with sudden coughing and wheezing after eating peanuts. A chest X-ray is taken and shown below. What is the most likely type of bronchial obstruction?
questions.explanation:
Common Location

Right bronchus (due to its wider lumen and alignment with the trachea)

Clinical Triad

Cough, wheezing, and diminished air entry to the lung.

Late Features

Lung collapse, emphysema, pneumonitis, bronchiectasis, or lung abscess.

Types of Obstruction
  • Partial Obstruction: (Option B)
    • Air can pass in and out
    • Cause only wheezing
  • One-way Obstruction: (Option D)
    • Air can enter (during inspiration) but not exit
    • Cause emphysema of the lungs
  • Total Obstruction: (Option A)
    • Air cannot enter or exit
    • Cause obstructive atelectasis
  • One-way Obstruction (reverse of B):
    • Air can exit (during expiration) but not enter
    • Cause atelectasis

Complication

  • Obstructive Emphysema: Air trapped in the lungs due to a check-valve mechanism.
  • Spontaneous Pneumothorax: Due to rupture of emphysematous bullae.
  • Lung Collapse: Due to complete bronchial obstruction.
  • Chronic Complications: Retained foreign bodies may lead to pneumonitis, bronchiectasis, or lung abscess.

Investigation

  • Plain X-ray Chest (PA and Lateral Views):
  • Fluoroscopy/Videofluoroscopy: Evaluation during inspiration and expiration can be made.
  • CT Chest

Management

  • Emergency removal of foreign bodies is not typically indicated unless:
    • Airway obstruction is present.
    • Foreign bodies are of vegetable origin (e.g., seeds) and are likely to swell.
  • Methods for Foreign Body Removal:
  1. Conventional rigid bronchoscopy.
  2. Rigid bronchoscopy with telescopic aid.
  3. Bronchoscopy with C-arm fluoroscopy.
  4. Use a Dormia basket or Fogarty's balloon for rounded objects.
  5. Tracheostomy first followed by bronchoscopy through the tracheostome.
  6. Thoracotomy and bronchotomy for peripheral foreign bodies.
  7. Flexible fiberoptic bronchoscopy in selected adult patients.
